paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper describes a novel KCNH2 mutation (P1086fs+32X) associated with Long QT Syndrome (LQT2) in a proband and her brother, detailing penetrance data and functional studies.

patients.phenotype: Proband presented with ventricular fibrillation and QTc prolongation; brother had mild QTc prolongation.

individual_records.phenotype_details: Suffered a ventricular fibrillation arrest following a minor automobile accident; QTc of 554 ms.
individual_records.evidence_sentence: The proband was a 33-year old female with no prior cardiac history, who suffered a ventricular fibrillation arrest following a minor automobile accident.

individual_records.phenotype_details: Asymptomatic but manifested mild QTc prolongation (451 ms) with bifid T waves.
individual_records.evidence_sentence: The proband's 28-year-old brother was asymptomatic, but manifested mild QTc prolongation (451 ms) with bifid T waves.

functional_data.summary: The mutation results in a dominant-negative effect, leading to degraded non-functional channels.

variants.segregation_data: The same LQT2 mutation was found in the proband and her brother, indicating segregation.
variants.evidence_level: strong evidence based on functional studies and family segregation.
variants.additional_notes: The mutation is a frameshift that leads to a truncated protein.
key_quotes: Mutation analysis revealed an autosomal dominant frameshift mutation at proline 1086 (P1086fs+32X; 3256InsG).
This study demonstrates a novel dominant-negative Kv11.1 mutation, which results in degraded non-functional channels leading to a LQT2 phenotype.

extraction_metadata.notes: All relevant data was extracted from the main text.
